title: Domain 2.2: Explain common threat vectors and attack surfaces.
content:
🎯 Threat Vectors

  • 💬 Message-based:
    • Email: Phishing and malware delivery.
    • SMS: Smishing attacks using text messages.
    • Instant Messaging (IM): Attacks via apps like Slack, Teams, WhatsApp.
  • 🖼️ Image-based: Malware hidden in image files using steganography or exploits.
  • 📄 File-based: Malware embedded in PDFs, Word docs, or executables.
  • 📞 Voice call: Vishing scams using phone calls or robocalls.
  • 💾 Removable device: Malware via USBs or external storage.
  • 🐞 Vulnerable software: Exploits targeting unpatched software or plugins.
  • 🧱 Unsupported systems: End-of-life software lacking updates (e.g., Windows 7).

🌐 Unsecure Networks

  • Wireless: Open Wi-Fi is risky if not encrypted.
  • Wired: More secure but vulnerable with physical access.
  • Bluetooth: Prone to attacks like bluejacking or unauthorized access.

🚪 Open Service Ports

Unmonitored ports (e.g., RDP, FTP) provide entry points for attackers.

🗝️ Default Credentials

Factory-set usernames/passwords must be changed to prevent easy compromise.

🔗 Supply Chain Risks

  • Managed Service Providers (MSPs): If compromised, the client is also at risk.
  • Vendors: May introduce vulnerabilities via software/hardware.
  • Suppliers: Third-party logistics or manufacturing can introduce risk.

🧠 Human Vectors / Social Engineering

  • 🎣 Phishing: Deceptive messages to trick users into revealing info.
  • 📞 Vishing: Voice phishing via fake calls from trusted sources.
  • 📱 Smishing: Malicious links in SMS messages.
  • 📰 Misinformation: False info shared unknowingly.
  • 📰 Disinformation: False info shared intentionally.
  • 🕵️ Impersonation: Pretending to be someone trusted for access or data.
  • 📧 BEC: Business Email Compromise, spoofing execs to initiate fraud.
  • 🎭 Pretexting: Creating fake stories to trick users into revealing info.
  • 💧 Watering Hole Attack: Infecting frequently visited sites to catch users.
  • 🏷️ Brand Impersonation: Fake sites/emails mimicking real brands.
  • ✏️ Typosquatting: Registering misspelled domains to catch mistyped traffic.
